results.title: My Brilliant Career paperback
results.brief_description: My Brilliant Career, adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_primary.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

results.title: It wasn't me
results.creator_credit: Eddie Moses, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1978 film consists of a short narrative demonstrating the need for observing industrial safety standards on building sites. The film’s cast of characters includes a wealthy contractor, a negligent foreman, a disgruntled safety warden, a foreign labourer and a department inspector, as they attempt to reconstruct what happened to a missing worker following a trench collapse. Each of the characters avoids responsibility in their roles and blames the others for the accident. Presented as a dramatic short with points of comedy (though this is mainly through the slapstick representation of an Italian worker who doesn’t speak English), the film emphasises the importance of all members of the workforce taking responsibility for upholding safe practices on site.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Peter Aanensen, Frank Bansel, Brendan Cassidy, Cul Cullen, Cliff Ellen, Don Glover, Peter Kay, Kevin Lacey, Robert Larkins, Sue Ellen Peers, Robert Ward

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: It wasn't easy
results.creator_credit: Nico Crama, Arthur Hammond, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Half a million people of Dutch origin live in Canada. This film looks at the unique character of the Dutch Canadians, their reasons for leaving the Netherlands and their contribution to Canadian society and culture. A cross section of Dutch Canadians living across Canada are interviewed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nico Crama, Arthur Hammond, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: It took a thief to stop a thief
results.creator_credit: Randy Grinter, Walter Shaw, Media Productions and Is Your Home Safe Inc
results.brief_description: This video covers everything from criminal attitude to locks, alarm systems, lighting, windows and position of the house. The video explores ways in which your house can be made more secure. Hosted by Walter Shaw with Eddie Egan.

results.title: It takes a lot of help
results.creator_credit: John Peer Nugent and Core Communications Group
results.brief_description: Uses music by the Beatles, with narration by Lorne Greene, to explore the numerous avenues available to groups of citizens who are concerned with preventing drug abuse. Describes various of these avenues available both to the inidividual and communities combating drug abuse.
